subject: Business
title: Financial Bubbles: When Prices Detach from Reality
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Financial Bubbles: When Prices Detach from Reality.

hook.text: In 1637, a single tulip bulb cost more than a Amsterdam house. Weeks later, the market collapsed entirely.

buildup.text: A bubble forms when asset prices rise far beyond intrinsic value, driven by speculation and fear of missing out.

discovery.text: Every bubble follows the same pattern: displacement, boom, euphoria, profit-taking, and panic.

twist.text: During bubbles, rational people look foolish for not participating. The crowd makes speculation seem like genius.

climax.text: The 2008 housing bubble wiped out $7 trillion in US household wealth. Bubbles always end.

punchline.text: When everyone thinks prices can only go up, they're about to go down.

quiz.question: What drives a financial bubble?
options: Speculation and fear of missing out push prices far beyond intrinsic value
A sudden increase in product quality
